div1.p: Kean finds Roper's book admirable, in substance and in literary style. He mentions that her dramatic style of writing has caused her to rely heavily on her imagination. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Laura Wood Roper, April 25, 1943
div1.opener:
W.R. and Y.F.
Copy
To Miss Laura R. Wood
April 25, 1943
Dear Miss Laura.
div1.p:
I realize well that my letter of the
17th must have been a disappointment to you, as it
amounted simply to being an acknowledgement of the
receipt of your book with my thanks & a promise to
write again. Since then I have read it all and
thought much about it. By your selection of the dra-
matic method of telling your story - by which I mean
you do it by putting the words in the months of the
dramatic personal and hearing them do it in the
parts of vital interest and importance, you have
added greatly to the vividness and interest of your
story. At the same time you have made a heavy
demand on your imagination. Like the novelist
you have made it necessary to evolve a clear cut
quite definite and more or less intimate conception
of each one, so that in a group you have had to
select the right man to tell his part of the story
and use the appropriate words which he would use to
say it. A novelist has a great advantage
over the historian in that the characters in the for-
mer's story have no existence outside of his mind
and so in the act of their creation he gives them veri-
similitude: whereas the historian in his story
if told dramatically has to fit his acts and words
to individuals who have a personality known
known more or less accurately to their friends and
2
acquaintances. This is some job, and even if
you knew Reed and his assistants and family
and the other important persons in this great
episode, as well as Truby and I for example
knew them, you could not make the picture too
true to life as we saw it. You could not bring
out some of the shadows in the picture. Carroll's
dislike of Agramonte (which the latter fully returned)
or his jealously of his Chief and benefactor Reed,
which let him to consider himself as the real hero
who was robbed of the credit of leadership and
discovery by Reed and his friends because the
latter was a member of the regular Medical Corps
while he was only a contract doctor at that time.
They had five points too. Of course you could
not bring this out in your story, you had more
or less to idealize them. ↓ - But I would
not put into Carroll's mouth the proposition
that the board members would take the first
risk (p. 205) His was the first case only because
Lazears first bite was not ripe. Carroll did
not for a minute believe in the Finlay theory.
You may be sure that Reed made that statement.
I mention this not as a fault in the book, but
as an illustrative of the extraordinary diffi-
culty of your task. The visit to Finlay, and
who went with Reed, as well as when they went
are interesting questions about which I have no
3
JRK to L N Wood
first-hand information. Dean Cornwell,
the painter came to see me to get what infor-
mation I had, some months before he painted
the Conquerors of Yellow Fever. I did not have
much to give him as I was away from Cuba
on sick leave from July 3 to Aug 13, 1900
But I advised him to paint the patio
scene with only Finlay & Reed & his assistants.
I always thought Reeds visit to Finlay was
before the Pinar del Rio Epidemic. I see you
place it after, but in your Appendix II admit
that it is not definitely known. These details
are of interest, but not of cardinal importance.
You have told all of the important facts with
admirable accuracy and clarity. It is
altogether an admirable book, in substance
and in literary style. I hope you have
made the Publisher send copies to General
Truby and to Col Hench. His last address
was the Broadmoor Hotel, Colorado Springs, Colo.
I am sure they will both be much pleased
with it, and all of us will be proud of the
generous credit you have given us.

closer.salute:
With my very hearty congratulations and Easter
Greetings I am very cordially yours
closer.seg:
P.S. Mrs Kean did not come back to Cuba with me on Aug 13/00
She came on the boat with Reed and I met them Oct. 3 at
matanzas & came to Havana with them Oct. 4 I told Reed the
news of the death of Lazear then.
